The following are statements by Ayn Rand. "The end does not justify the means. No one's rights can be secured by the violation of the rights of others." "No man can have a right to impose an unchosen obligation, an unrewarded duty or an involuntary servitude on another man. There can be no such thing as the right to enslave." "An individualist is a man who says: "I will not run anyone's life - nor let anyone run mine. I will not rule or be ruled. I will not be a master nor a slave. I will not sacrifice myself to anyone - nor sacrifice anyone to myself." 
 
 Rand I think is very rhetorically savvy but her theories don't seem to hold water for me.
 
 First of all, its unstable and inconsistant. Look to her third quote ("an individualist is a man..."). In effect, the man is being "ruled" in that he is conceding his ability to take certain actions (ex: enslaving others). He is a slave to a certain dogma. While I don't have a huge problem with this insofar as it means I am morally bound not to kill others for example, I think it also hurts more noble ends. Specifically, when she claims that one must "not sacrifice [oneself] to anyone," that goes beyond saying that one isn't obligated to help others and moves into the realm of saying one is OBLIGATED not to help others, even if one wants to. That isn't true freedom, because it enforces a certain view of the world onto individuals who may "freely" see it differently (I may WANT to help others, b/c I'm a nice, friendly guy!)
 
 Second, Isiah Berlin points out one major problem with her perception of liberty "Liberty does not just mean freedom of action, but also (and equally) freedom from the consequences of other's actions." The consequentialist aspect of liberty needs to be valued too. Look to her first quote. There are at least as many situations where the MEANS are just, but the ends AREN'T to certain people. This generally happens when their is a gross power imbalance between two negotiating groups (Rand claims that the ideal relation between humans is as merchants or traders, because they theoretically can freely enter agreements w.out coercion. But she doesn't seem to realize the socio-political realities that make even nominally "non-coercive" negotiations into entirely onesided affairs). If I find a man stranded on a desert island, and I offer to rescue him for the price of him becoming my man-servant for the next year, that isn't a "just" action even if we both agree to it, because the power structure is so skewed. For the man on the island to be truely free, he must also be free from the consequence of my decision not to take him off the island, but he's effectively bound to me because the alternative is death. The Randian world doesn't offer him solvency because it refuses to step in and give me a positive obligation to take him off the island. Keep in mind that this "contract" is entirely consistant with Rand's second quote, as the person IS being rewarded (with food). Essentially, ONE of us will lose his freedom, but the tunnelvision Rand uses (which only deals with half of liberty) doesn't account for it. This ends up being the worst problem with the Randian ethos, because ALOT of rights violations come out of oppressive relations between the privileged and the subordinated. The poor consistantly are bargaining with the rich but they have no leverage and thus can continually be exploited. The rich neither have an obligation nor an incentive to change the terms of the contract to put the poor on equal terms. So while the poor may be "free" in one sense of the term, they are effectively locked into an exploitative system. Monwarul Islam remarks "The call for a level playing field sounds so convincing as to make us often forget that a fair game on a level playing field can only occur amongst comparable players, not between giants and dwarves." Rand may create a level playing field, but the giants can still stomp on the dwarves. And since the giants have the same advantage in political negotiations as they do in any other negotiation, they can "rig the rules" so they are maintain the status quo and insure that the framework by which we view "fairness" in the game is one that helps the giants. Rand herself, for example, is a product of a viewpoint that sees theoritical liberty as the ultimate value. However, this can hardly be made into a normative claim. A starving street urchin would probably value provision of basic needs higher. Within Rand's framework, feeding poor people at the expense of agrobusiness freedom isn't fair. Within the poor person framework, allowing agrobusiness total freedom while people starve isn't fair. The Berlin/Mill view of freedom, reconciles the two by bringing into the equation substantive liberty (the second half of Berlin's formulation).
 
 Third, Rand only protects a narrow definition of rights. First of all, any notion of a positive right is entirely lost in a Randian world, I am not "owed" anything, I only "possess" rights that can't be taken away. This may be a fine formulation, but it is constricting and I am certainly hesistant to catagorically close off any possibilty of the existance of positive rights. Are individuals "owed" basic needs? How about human dignity? And even if adults aren't owed them, are children? I would assert there is a positive right to equality of oppurtunity at least, but Rand doesn't provide a mechanism for enforcement of it. Actually, enforcement is a big problem in a Randian world, even in terms of negative rights, because how do you account for someone simply ignoring the morality of the system? Since the ends of protecting others rights DOESN'T justify the infringement on the rights of the aggressor, the system is self defeating.
 
 Finally, Rand's logic in creating her formulation seems to beg the question. She claims altruism is bad because it is a moral formulation that requires suffering for one to be virtuous, while egoism doesn't. However, this seems abit Ivory Tower for me. Suffering does exist, the question is how we deal with it. I'd agree that if there was no suffering, we shouldn't create it so we can feel good about ourselves. But Rand confuses the syllogism that altruism operates off of. All altruism claims is that where suffering exists, one has an obligation to mitigate it. Where there is no suffering, one has no obligation. Rand proposes we stick our head in the sand, if we pretend we don't see suffering it will go away (or at least carry no moral weight). But since I am profoundly skeptical that the suffering DOES go away (or that ignoring it removes its importance), Rand's warrant collapses on itself.
 
 The bottom line is that Rand/egoism presents just one aspect of individualism. I don't like objectivism because I think its defense of rights is unconvincing, further more, I think it enables an oppressive system under the guise of equality by purporting to "level the playing field." I think Berlin and Mill present a superior system because of the broader definition of liberty. I have the negative right to live my life free of interference except where I'd be interefering with someone else's liberty, and I have the positive right to anything which is required for me to exercise my liberty fully.
Darkest Shadow

 Hi billsco,
 I probably could have worded that better. I meant to say that happiness is a sensible place to end up at, but for me at least, worrying on a day-to-day basis about being happy tends to make me peasure-seek, but long-term pleasure-seeking leads to a feeling of emptiness and an enduring kind of happiness is not found this way. I think the happiest people are very energetically involved in productive activities that they care about, are interested in, and are good at. As you say, you may never achieve anything particularly memorable, but you'll will get satisfaction from having been productive and having perfected your craft. 
 
 I think I wrote before that research shows that satisfying relationships are a key to happiness for most people. And depending on your preferences, you may find helping others to be the most satisfying activity, and I don't see these as being at all incomptabile with my idea of achievement. If you work hard to be the best partner, parent, or helper you can be--to achieve in the people area--you're still going with the natural motivation to maximize yourself, but you end up achieving a great deal in enriching the lives of other people, and people tend to give back what you give them, and you end up being happy as a result.
